data.title: [Pipeline Tool] Fix new folder action
data.body:
Internally Pipeline Tool is using "/" for paths.

Fixes #4847

data.title: Monogame template install error
data.body:
I already posted this in the community section at the monogame website, but didn't get an answer yet, so I decided to post it here as well.

I tried to install Monogame 3.5 for Visual Studio 2015 on Windows 10.
The setup throws an error when trying to install the templates. It says "Unable to open file to write" on every Template-ZIP. It also doesn't create the Monogame subfolder in the Visual Studio 2015...\Templates\Visual C# folder.

I have administrator rights and executed the setup as administrator. I disabled my Anti-Virus for the installation.
The Visual C# folder had the "write protected" setting in the half-checked state that you get when a program is currently using the folder. Visual Studio is not open though and I don't know how to find out which program currently uses the folder.

I think I would just need the template ZIP files as download to manually copy them to the folder or a fix for my installer problem.
Can I just install the WindowsUniversal.vstemplate from the GIT folder (I won't need the other templates)? How?

Edit: I found out that this issue is a copy of [Can't install templates](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/4838). I also moved my Libraries to D:\ volume like the creator of that issue.
However, my other question about manually installing the templates still stands and I would appreciate an answer.

data.title: pipeline tool: can't create directory inside directory
data.body: Create a directory in the pipeline tool. Then click that directory, right button, add new folder. Folder is created in the root of the project, not inside the selected directory.

data.title: Major issues with file linking in pipeline tool
data.body:
I don't know if they're documented (I've searched the issues and found nothing, but those could be there and I just didn't find them).
- Adding a folder as a link works wrong. Instead of adding the folder, and inside of it, the files it contains, it just adds all files and directories at the same level.
- When saving and reloading a project where the previous step has been performed, the containing folder disappears.
- When deleting those added files, instead of deleting the link, it tries to delete the file (i.e. in ......\file.png), which can permanently destroy data the user thinks is safe. 
- When building linked data, the output directory should be defined by the pipeline tool folder structure, not the original place where the linked file is. In example, if the data is in d:\asset and the mgcb file is in d:\mgcb, and I create a directory (in the pipeline tool) named  myXNB, and we create a linked file pointing to d:\asset\mytex.png inside myXNB, the output directory should be myXNB, however the pipeline tool tries to create it at d:\assets\myXNB.xnb
- Adding a file as a link just copies it (I'm not sure of it , it my just be a problem masked by the previous issues)

data.title: OpenAssetImporter now also imports node animations (not only skeleton)
data.body: includes a simple unit test

data.title: [Pipeline Tool] Few minor improvements
data.body:
Stuff done:
- updates submodule
- removes Ctrl + C "Close" shortcut
- makes propertygrid dialog starting different depending if it's on Windows/Unix to properly resolve their drawings

data.title: Garbage reduction: GraphicsDevice.SetRenderTarget

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
Add a `RenderTargetBinding[1]` member to `GraphicsDevice`.  In the implementations of `GraphicsDevice.SetRenderTarget(RenderTarget2D)` and `GraphicsDevice.SetRenderTarget(RenderTargetCube, CubeMap)`, populate the array with 'new RenderTargetBinding`and the parameters passed, then pass that array to the internal call to`SetRenderTargets()`.

This eliminates the garbage generated by the compiler-generated code to handle the `params`-style parameter lists.

data.title: Why is EffectResource internal? This would be helpful
data.body: I was trying to go through basic 3d tutorials the other night (mostly old xna ones) and I keep running into the problem of having to build out my own effect. Why can't we have basic ones provided by monogame directly? It's an annoying pain to do it yourself when the framework already has some basics for you when you don't want to do anything special but render a simple object to the screen.

data.title: Windows.ClientBounds doesn't appear to be correct after a window resize
data.body: **Verified see below** This is the current build right now. For a Windows Dx project Windows.Clientbounds is not only incorrect, but when resizing the window, scaling is taking place on all drawing. That should not be occurring at all. This is counter to the behavior in xna. see the image notes In the below image i have reduced the size of the window im guessing about 10 to 20 % Everything dis-aligns including just normally drawn text underneath the mouse and draws. Im seeing improper scaling occurring, where it should not be occurring at all. _Note as i shrink the window the un-scaled fps text in white shrinks to fit the window, it should not. At the same time my manually scaled to screen images and text is being disaligned. The mouse also is not aligned to text drawn at its position after resizing the window_ **DX just downloaded and built** RE: i just verified it, using a older open gl version template i know worked. The below image the window is shrunk far further with no bugs. The data chunks scale straight to the window no matter how i resize it correctly. the current windows dx version is bugged im on win7 vs 2013. _Note the fps text in white here is not scaled and gets cut off as i shrink the window properly. The exact same code in a older gl version the manually scaled images work normally_ **GL older version** I cant build for the new gl version to test it because half the project is missing from the solution.

data.title: Fix TitleSafeArea

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
Looks like we've not implemented TitleSafeArea in MonoGame:

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/Viewport.cs#L145
https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/DisplayMode.cs#L6
7

In XNA it was 20% of the screen, but see the notes Chuck Walbourn (XNA dev) that he left for us on this: https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/4697#issuecomment-217779403.

We should be able to do 10% now as no one uses CRTs.

data.title: monogame pipeline keybinding for close

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
Hi,

monogame pipeline (windows) uses Control+C for closing. Is it possible to change it? (i.e. to Control+W which is a more standard windows closing keybinding). Current keybinding makes impossible to copy text from the output.

data.title: Can't install templates.
data.body: I can't install templates when i'm using the installer. I suspect it is because my documents library folder is on D: on C:. I tried to copy the template from another computer but that didn't seem to work.  Let me know if there is any workarounds.

data.title: Memory consumption FNA vs Monogame
data.body:
I've started this subjet on twitter : https://twitter.com/oldteen_tt/status/729763421240098816

Brief history of my case:
- I am trying to make a game based on FNA
- I want to try android/ios/xbox one support, so I compile my code with monogame 3.6
- And I see these ram conssumption for my game running in debug mode : with FNA +- 100MB and with monogame +-200MB

After make some tests, monogame memory consumption follow the backbuffer size. In 4k my game eat more than 300MB with monogame and stay at 100MB with FNA. (the others values was in 1080p)

I've made a new test with the code output by monogame template, just change the backbuffer size
**4k**
fna : 50MB
MG : 150 MB
**1080p**
fna : 50MB
MG : 93 MB
**640x360**
fna : 50MB
MG : 65 MB

Did I forget something ? a parameter ?
I know that 3.6 is not a finished version, but I am curious, maybe too much ;)

I hope these informations can help or I hope that I've made a mistake.

Edit: I use DesktopGL template

data.title: Fix incorrect use of startIndex in Texture2D.GetData DX

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
Implement the tests that demonstrate the bug stated in #4832.
While readying the test found another difference compared to XNA and added another test for that: XNA throws an `ArgumentException` if the `elementCount` parameter is less than the area of the `Rectangle` from where to get the Texture data.

data.title: Directx Texture2D.PlatformGetData bug
UWP Targets and Rooted File Access
data.body:
In addition to TitleContainer file system access, UWP apps fully support
read and write access to ApplicationData.Current.LocalFolder and
KnownFolder directories (Music Library, Pictures) with package declarations.  Not sure 
it is the role of MonoGame to restrict access to the TitleContainer subfolder
exclusively if a rooted path is requested on the the UWP platform.
If access to a rooted folder is invalid an access denied exception is always
thrown for UWP platform targets (Windows 8, Windows 10, Windows Phone,
XB1) due to sandboxing.  This proposed code change adds WINDOWS_UAP to the list of platform
targets which allow rooted file system access.

data.title: 3.6 template DesktopGL / vs2013-2015
data.body:
Hello,

I am trying 3.6 Dev Build with vs2013 or 2015 and the template DesktopGL.
- The project is created, perfect.
- I press F5, compile, launch the program, and get the message "SDL2.dll missing"
- ok, I copy sdl2.dll in my debug folder
- Press F5 again and get a "vshost32 stop to run" message (but in french :) )

Did I forgot something? I didn't modify the code created by the template. Maybe my sdl2.dll is wrong version (2.0.4.0) ?

In my debug folder I've got :
- monogame.framework.dll
- nvorbis.dll
- openTK.dll
- openTK.dll.config
- test1.exe
- test1.exe.config
- test1.pdb
- test1.vshost.exe
- test1.vshost.exe.config
- test1.vshost.exe.manifest

I have added : sdl2.dll and openal32.dll (to try...)

I hope I don't push at open doors and sorry for my english!
Thanks for all your job
oldteen

data.title: XB1 UWP doesn't like how our static VBs and IBs are created

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
For some reason on XB1 via UWP both `VertexBuffer` and `IndexBuffer` fail to work, but `DynamicVertexBuffer` and `DynamicIndexBuffer` work fine.

What is particularly curious about this is that things work perfectly fine under UWP on Windows 10 desktops and on UWP under Raspberry Pi.  Also the exact same code works on Windows 7, Vista, and Windows 8.  It is just on XB1 where the non-dynamic buffers fail to work.

I suspect it is either something something in buffer setup:

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/Vertices/VertexBuffer.DirectX.cs#L44

Or it is something in the buffer `SetData` which takes a different path for dynamic vs static buffers:
  https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/Vertices/VertexBuffer.DirectX.cs#L121

It could very well be that the code that has worked for 5 years now on every other DX platform has been wrong and the drivers and/or the DX runtime has been letting us get away with it.

data.title: HLSL buffers incorrectly calculated?
data.body:
I have a shader that causes an ArgumentException, "Offset and length were out of bounds for the array or count is greater than the number of elements from index to the end of the source collection."

The stack trace is as follows:
   at System.Buffer.BlockCopy(Array src, Int32 srcOffset, Array dst, Int32 dstOffset, Int32 count)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ConstantBuffer.SetData(Int32 offset, Int32 rows, Int32 columns, Object data)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ConstantBuffer.SetParameter(Int32 offset, EffectParameter param)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ConstantBuffer.Update(EffectParameterCollection parameters)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EffectPass.Apply()

After some really low-level probing, I was able to determine that the effect's ConstantBuffer(s) seems to have been incorrectly allocated. My vertex shader has four float4x4 parameters, and as such, the offsets are correctly set as 0, 64, 128, 192. However, the ConstantBuffer's buffer is only 240 bytes, rather than the necessary 256. It looks as though it's reading that sizeInBytes figure from the compiled shader effect code, so does that mean the HLSL compiler is doing something wrong? Or is there something else that I'm overlooking?

data.title: Mouse event handler works inconsistently on Xamarin.Mac but is fine on MonoMac
data.body:
I've tried doing mouse drag event handling in both MonoGame base and MonoGame.Extended and for some reason Xamarin.Mac projects do not work as expected while MonoMac projects work fine.  I can capture drag events with the middle mouse button but the right and left mouse buttons do not drag.  I tried this with some XNA drag and drop code I ported, and then further tested with a brand new project using the the MonoGame.Extended InputListener Demo code.  

This seems like a bug where the mouse movement events aren't firing for some reason while the button is in a pressed state.

data.title: RasterizerState.DepthBias not working as expected

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
The DepthBias in MonoGame is not working the same way as in XNA.
I'm not 100% sure, but it looks like XNA is applying the DepthBias value set in RasterizerState in a way that matches the depth buffer format.

In XNA I have used a value of -0.0004f (this is quite much) to offset a transparent area border above the landscape.

This didn't work at all in MonoGame and after some investigation I found out that MonoGame just passes the value to DirectX without modification and DirectX applies it as a factor to a very small number that is calculated based on the depth buffer format.

My theory now is that XNA does some math with the DepthBias value to make it easier for the developer to deal with it.

In my case (24bit depth buffer) the following formula gives exactly the same visual result as -0.0004f in XNA:
`state.DepthBias = (float)(-0.0004f / (1 / Math.Pow(2, 24)))`

data.title: [SpriteBatch] Optimize _tempRect
data.body: Skip expensive operations when sourceRectangle is `null`.

data.title: Add Color(uint) and Color(byte,byte,byte,byte) Constructors

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.title: Tests for Texture2d.FromStream
data.body:
Related to #4820 
This implements the test for Textures with `Alpha=0` and `Alpha=129`, both tests work on XNA, but the second one fails on Monogame.

data.title: Re-import XNA ContentProj
data.body:
Currently the Pipleine tool has a "Import..." feature that can import an existing XNA .contentproj creating a new MGCB content project.

It would be a nice addition to have the option to import into an existing MBCB content project, ignoring duplicate entries, and adding any new ones.  This would allow you to update a MonoGame content project with changes from an XNA .contentproj.

data.title: No MonoDevelop project templates install on the Linux version

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
Unlike Visual Studio on Windows and Xamarin on Mac, if you install the Linux version (at least by using the Ubuntu install instructions) no project templates install into MonoDevelop so you're stuck using another operating system to create an empty project and then opening that project in Linux.  You should just be able to select a MonoGame template when you create a new MonoDevelop project.

This seems like an easy enough fix so I'm happy to try to tackle it myself if nobody else is working on it.

data.title: Texture2D.FromStream Test
data.body:
This is something I noticed in XNA behavior porting a game to PS4.

If you have a texture that is filled with the color:  `R:255 G:128 B:64 A:0`.  When you load this texture via `Texture2D.FromStream` the resulting texture has the color: `R:0 G:0 B:0 A:0`.

If you have a texture that is filled with the color:  `R:255 G:128 B:64 A:1`...  `Texture2D.FromStream` returns a texture with the color: `R:255 G:128 B:64 A:1`.

So although the XNA docs for `Texture2D.FromStream` explicitly state that it returns non-premultiplied colors... it does however clear the color channels if the alpha channel is 0.

I don't know if MonoGame matches XNA in this regard or not.  We need to implement a specific unit test with a special test texture to verify the results.

Secondarily we should consider adding an overload that lets you disable this color channel clearing as it was unexpected.  I can see how it would be useful to not have it modify the loaded color data.
